awd_titl_txt: Novel Multiple-Shooting Algorithms for Optimization Governed by Time-Dependent Partial Differential Equations
awd_abstract_narration:
Mathematical optimization plays a crucial role in the optimal design of engineering systems and in their efficient operation. For example, management of oil reservoirs requires the injection of, e.g., water into wells to push oil reserves through complex geological structures to production wells with the goal to maximize revenue. Systems like this are modeled by time-dependent partial differential equations (PDEs) and involve many design or decision variables, such as injection rates that vary among wells and over time, that need to be determined. This research develops new mathematical optimization algorithms for such time-dependent problems.  
 
Specifically, this research aims to develop new algorithms for the efficient application of direct multiple shooting (MS) formulations to optimal control and optimal design problems governed by time dependent PDEs, and demonstrates the performance of these algorithms to applications in flow control. Direct MS formulations decompose the underlying PDEs into equations on shorter time subintervals and couple these at the time interval boundaries. These coupling conditions must be satisfied at the solution, but not during the iteration of an optimization algorithm. This is exploited to achieve substantial improvements in the numerical solution of such problems through superior stability properties of sub-problems, enhanced convergence properties of solution algorithms, and introduction of parallelism. However, MS formulations have a price: The auxiliary initial data at time interval boundaries are additional optimization variables and the coupling conditions are additional constraints. For problems governed by (discretized) PDEs this leads to huge increases in the number of optimization variables and constraints. Because of these increases, existing optimization approaches that have been successfully applied to MS formulations of problems governed by ordinary differential equations are practically infeasible in the PDE setting. The goals of this research are to 1) inject MS formulations into first-order gradient optimization algorithms to expand their applicability to problems where the solution of the underlying PDE may be numerically unstable and 2) develop new second-order iterative methods based on model reduction to substantially reduce the computational cost of solving large quadratic-programs that arise in conventional sequential quadratic programming approaches. Convergence analysis of the new methods will be provided and these methods will be demonstrated on applications in flow control.

por.por_cntn:
This project has developed algorithms and convergence analyses for optimization problems governed by time dependent partial differential equations (PDEs), and it has studied specific optimization problems. The numerical solution of optimization problems governed by time dependent PDEs by gradient based optimization methods explicitly or implicitly involves solution of a coupled system of PDEs, which makes this task computationally challenging. 

The optimization algorithms developed in this project are based on problem decompositions and solve collections of smaller scale problems, with suitable couplings that ensure convergence to the solution of the original problems. Typically, the smaller scale problems can be solved in parallel, and each small-scale problem solution requires substantially less memory than the original problems. Broadly speaking, this project has considered three different algorithmic directions: (1) Alternating Direction Method of Multipliers (ADMM) based methods applied to time decompositions of the optimal control problem, (2) multilevel-in-time methods based on time decompositions of the optimal control problem, and (3) solvers and preconditioners based on diagonalization. 

The algorithms have been demonstrated on several example problems arising in optimal control of time dependent PDEs, a problem class that appears in many science and engineering applications. Towards the end of the project, extensions of the developed optimization methods based on  time decomposition to training of recurrent neural networks (RNNs) were explored. While these training problems do not involve PDE constraints, their mathematical structure shares some of the features (large-scale, time-like structure represented by the layers in the RNN) that the proposed algorithms build on. 

This project has partially supported three PhD students. Results of the project were integrated into courses on the theory and applications of optimization as well as into special courses or lectures on PDE constrained optimization aimed at students in both mathematics and engineering.
